node.html:
An algorithm is is greedy if it builds up a solution in small steps, choosing a decision at each step myopically to optimize some underlying criterion. One can often design many different greedy algorithms for the same problem, each one locally, incrementally optimizing some measure on its way to a solution.

Coin Changing

Goal: Given US currency denominations {1,5,10,25,100}\{1, 5, 10, 25, 100\}{1,5,10,25,100}, devise a method to pay amount to customer using fewest coins.

Algorithm: At each iteration, add coin of the largest value that does not take us past the amount to be paid.

cashiers-algorithm(x, ...cn):
  sort n coin denominations so that 0 < c1 < c2 < .. < cn
  S = {} # multiset of coins selected

  while x > 0:
    k = largest coin denomination ck such that ck <= x
    if no such k:
      return "no solution"
    else:
      x = x - ck
      S = S + {k}

  return S

Cashier's algorithm is optimal for US coin denominations. And it also may even lead to a feasible solution:

  • Consider if c1>1c_1 > 1c1​>1: 7, 8, 9:

    • Cashier's algorithm: 15 = 9 + ?
    • Optimal: 15 = 7 + 8

Interval Scheduling

Job jjj starts at sjs_jsj​ and finished at fjf_jfj​.

The basic idea in a greedy algorithm for interval scheduling is to use a simple rule to select a first request j1j_1j1​. Once a request j1j_1j1​ is selected, we reject all requests that are not compatible with j1j_1j1​. Then select the next request j2j_2j2​ to be accepted, and again reject all requests that are not compatible with j2j_2j2​. Two jobs are compatible if they don't overlap. The goal is to find maximum subset of mutually compatible jobs.

A greedy rule that leads to the optimal solution: accepts first the request that finishes first, that is, the request for which fjf_jfj​ is as small as possible.

earlist-finish-time-first(n, ...sn, ...fn):
  sort jobs by finish times and renumber such that f1 <= f2 <= ... <= fn
  S = {}
  for j = 1 to n:
    if job j is compatible with S:
      S = S + { j }
  
  return S

Proposition. Can implement earliest-finish-time first in O(nlog⁡n)O(n\log{n})O(nlogn) time.

  • keep track if job j∗j^*j∗ that was added last to SSS
  • job jjj is compatible with SSS if and only if sj≥fj∗s_j \geq f_{j^*}sj​≥fj∗​
  • sorting by finish times takes O(nlog⁡n)O(n\log{n})O(nlogn) time

Interval Partitioning

Let's say that some lecture jjj starts at sjs_jsj​ and finishes at fjf_jfj​. The goal is to find minimum number of classrooms to schedule all lectures so that no two lectures occur at the same time in the same room.

earlist-finish-time-first(n, ...sn, ...fn):
  sort lectures by their start time s1 <= s2 <= ... <= sn
  d = 0 # number of allocated classrooms
  for j = 1 to n:
    if lecture j is compatible with some classroom:
      schedule lecture j in any classroom k
    else:
      allocate new classroom d + 1
      schedule lecture j in classroom d + 1
      d = d + 1

  return schedule

Proposition: The earliest-start-time-first algorithm can be implemented in O(nlog⁡n)O(n\log{n})O(nlogn) time. Proof. Store classrooms in a priority queue (key = finish time of its last lecture):

  • To determine whether lecture jjj is compatible with some classroom, compare sjs_jsj​ to key of min classroom kkk in priority queue
  • To add lecture jjj to classroom kkk, increase key of classroom kkk to fjf_jfj​
  • Total number of priority queue operations is O(n)O(n)O(n)
  • Sorting by start times takes O(nlog⁡n)O(n\log{n})O(nlogn) time

Note that this implementation chooses a classroom kkk whose finish time of its last lecture is earliest.

Scheduling to Minimize Lateness

Optimal Caching

Gale-Shapley Algorithm & Stable Matching

  • Perfect matching MMM is a matching with the property that each member of MMM and each member of WWW appears in exactly one pair in MMM. A matching MMM is perfect if:
∣M∣=∣M∣=∣W∣=n|M| = |M| = |W| = n∣M∣=∣M∣=∣W∣=n

  • Given a perfect matching MMM, mmm and www form an unstable pair if both:

    • mmm prefers w′w'w′ to matched www
    • www prefers m′m'm′ to matched mmm

  • A stable matching is a perfect matching with no unstable pairs

    • stable matchings aren't obvious a priori
  • Time complexity of Gale-Shapley is O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2)

Algorithm Analysis

  • An algorithm is efficient if it has a polynomial running time

  • Upper bound: Big O

    • 0≤f(n)≤c⋅g(n)0 \leq f(n) \leq c \cdot g(n)0≤f(n)≤c⋅g(n) for all n≥n0n \geq n_0n≥n0​
    • lim⁡n→∞f(n)g(n)=0\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{f(n)}{g(n)} = 0limn→∞​g(n)f(n)​=0 (∈o(g(n))  ⟹  O(g(n))\in o(g(n)) \implies O(g(n))∈o(g(n))⟹O(g(n)), but not in Ω(g(n))\Omega(g(n))Ω(g(n)))

  • Lower bound: Big Ω\OmegaΩ

    • f(n)≥c⋅g(n)≥0f(n) \geq c \cdot g(n) \geq 0f(n)≥c⋅g(n)≥0 for all n≥n0n \geq n_0n≥n0​
    • lim⁡n→∞f(n)g(n)=∞\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{f(n)}{g(n)} = \inftylimn→∞​g(n)f(n)​=∞ (∈ω(g(n))  ⟹  Ω(g(n))\in \omega(g(n)) \implies \Omega(g(n))∈ω(g(n))⟹Ω(g(n)), but not in O(g(n))O(g(n))O(g(n)))

  • Tight bound: Big Θ\ThetaΘ

    • 0≤c1⋅g(n)≤f(n)≤c2⋅g(n)0 \leq c_1 \cdot g(n) \leq f(n) \leq c_2 \cdot g(n)0≤c1​⋅g(n)≤f(n)≤c2​⋅g(n)
    • lim⁡n→∞f(n)g(n)=c\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{f(n)}{g(n)} = climn→∞​g(n)f(n)​=c
  • In general: Factorial > Exponential > Polynomial > Log > Constant

Graphs

  • Adjacency matrix

    • n by n matrix with Auv=1A_{uv} = 1Auv​=1 if (u,v)(u, v)(u,v) is an edge
    • Two representations of each edge
    • Space proportional to n2n^2n2
    • Checking if (u,v)(u, v)(u,v) is an edge takes Θ(1)\Theta(1)Θ(1)
    • Identifying all edges takes O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2)

  • Adjacency list, node indexed array of lists

    • Two representations of each edge
    • Space is Θ(m+n)\Theta(m + n)Θ(m+n)
    • Checking if (u,v)(u, v)(u,v) is an edge takes O(degree(u))O(degree(u))O(degree(u)) time
    • Identifying all edges takes Θ(m+n)\Theta(m + n)Θ(m+n)

  • Path in an undirected graph is a sequence of nodes with the property that each consecutive pair vi−1,viv_{i - 1}, v_{i}vi−1​,vi​ is joined by an edge in EEE

    • a path is simple if all nodes are distinct
  • an undirected graph is connected if for every pair of nodes there's a path between them
  • a cycle is a path in which v1=vk,k>2v_1 = v_k, k > 2v1​=vk​,k>2 and the first k−1k - 1k−1 nodes are distinct
  • an undirected graph is a tree if it is connected and does not contain a cycle
  • Connected component: all nodes reachable from sss

  • BFS: explore outward from s in all possible directions adding nodes one "layer" at a time

    • Output of BFS results in a BFS tree with all the nodes in the graph that are connected to root sss
    • BFS runs in O(m+n)O(m + n)O(m+n) time if the graph is given by its adjacency representation

BFS pseudocode:

bfs(G, s):
  Q = empty queue
  Q.enqueue(s)
  mark s as visited

  while Q is not empty:
    v = Q.dequeue()

    for all neighbours u of v in G:
      if u is not visited:
        Q.enqueue(u)
        mark u as visited

  • DFS

    • Builds a connected component containing sss.
    • Visits the same set of nodes as BFS, but in different order →\to→ probes down
# To apply dfs to s-t connectivity,
# declare all nodes initially to be not explored
# then invoke dfs(s)

dfs(u):
  mark u as explored

  for each (u, v) incident to u:
    if v is not explored:
      dfs(v)

  • an undirected graph is bipartite if the nodes can be colored blue or white such that every edge has one white and one blue end.

    • if a graph is bipartite then it cannot contain an odd cycle
    • if a graph is bipartite no edge of GGG joins two nodes of the same layer
  • edge (u,v)(u, v)(u,v) leaves node uuu and enters node vvv
  • BFS extends to directed graphs
  • nodes uuu and vvv are mutually reachable if there is both a part from uuu to vvv and from vvv to uuu
  • a graph is strongly connected if every pair of nodes is mutually reachable
  • a strong component is a maximal subset of mutually reachable nodes
  • a Directed Acyclic Graph is a directed graph that contains no directed cycles
  • a topological order of a directed graph is an ordering of its nodes as v1,v2,...,vnv_1, v_2, ..., v_nv1​,v2​,...,vn​ for every edge (vi,vj)(v_i, v_j)(vi​,vj​), i<ji < ji<j
  • if G a graph has a topological order, then G is a DAG (and vice versa)
  • if G is a DAG, then G has a node with no entering edges

Greedy Algorithms

  • an algorithm is greedy if it builds up a solution in small steps, choosing a decision at each step myopically to optimize some underlying criterion
  • the challenge in designing a good greedy algorithm is in deciding which simple rule to use in selection.

  • Interval scheduling

    • Basic idea:
    • select first request i1i_1i1​
    • once i1i_1i1​ is accepted, reject all requests no compatible with i1i_1i1​
    • then select request i2i_2i2​ to be accepted and reject all requests not compatible with i2i_2i2​
    • repeat for all requests
# textbook version
earliestFinishTimeFirst():
  R = set() # set of all requests
  A = []

  while R is not empty:
    i = R.getSmallest() # choose smallest finishing time
    A.add(i)
    R.deleteIncompatibleWith(i) # delete all that are incompatible with i

  return A # optimal set

# slides version
earliestFinishTimeFirst(n, jobs):
  jobs.sort() # sort jobs by finish times, f1 <= f2 <= ... <= fn
  S = set()

  for j in range(n):
    if j.compatibleWith(S):
      S.union(j)

  return S
  • the earliest finish time first is optimal

  • Interval partitioning

    • implemented via earliest start time first
    • in any instance of interval partitioning the number of resources needed is at least the depth of the set of intervals
    • The greedy algorithm schedules every interval on a resource, using a number of resources equal to the depth of the set of intervals. This is the optimal number of resources needed.
# O(nlog(n))
earliestStartTimeFirst(n, startTimes, finishTimes):
  startTimes.sort() # sort by start times s1 <= s2 <= ... <= sn
  d = 0 # number of allocated classrooms

  for j in range(n):
    if j compatible with some classroom k:
      schedule j to k
    else:
      allocate new classroom d + 1
      schedule j in classroom d + 1
      d = d + 1

  return schedule

  • Scheduling to minimize lateness

    • single resource processes one job at a time =
    • job jjj requires tjt_jtj​ units of processing time and is due at time djd_jdj​
    • if jjj starts at time sjs_jsj​ it finishes at time fj=sj+tjf_j = s_j + t_jfj​=sj​+tj​
    • Lateness l=max(0,fj−dj)l = max(0, f_j - d_j)l=max(0,fj​−dj​)
    • Goal: schedule all jobs to minimize maximum lateness L=maxjljL = max_jl_jL=maxj​lj​

An algorithm is efficient if it has a polynomial running time. An algorithm is poly-time if when the input size doubles, the algorithm should slow down by at most some constant CCC.

Asymptotic order of growth

The growth rate of running times and other function should be expressed in a way that it is insensitive to constant factors and low-order terms.

Asymptotic Upper Bounds - Big OOO

Let f(n)f(n)f(n) be a function - the worst running case on an input of size nnn. Given function g(n)g(n)g(n), we can say that f(n)∈O(g(n))f(n) \in O(g(n))f(n)∈O(g(n)) - for sufficiently large nnn, f(n)f(n)f(n) is bounded above by a constant multiple of g(n)g(n)g(n). In other words, f(n)f(n)f(n) is O(g(n))O(g(n))O(g(n)) if there exist constants c>0c > 0c>0 and n0≥0n_0 \geq 0n0​≥0 such that:

0≤f(n)≤c⋅g(n) for all n≥n00 \leq f(n) \leq c \cdot g(n) \text{ for all } n \geq n_00≤f(n)≤c⋅g(n) for all n≥n0​

Note that O(⋅)O(\cdot)O(⋅) expresses only an upper bound, not the exact growth rate of the function.

Asymptotic Lower Bounds - Big Ω\OmegaΩ

f(n)f(n)f(n) is Ω(g(n))\Omega(g(n))Ω(g(n)) if there exist constants c>0c > 0c>0and n0≥0n_0 \geq 0n0​≥0 such that:

f(n)≥c⋅g(n)≥0 for all n≥n0f(n) \geq c \cdot g(n) \geq 0 \text{ for all } n \geq n_0f(n)≥c⋅g(n)≥0 for all n≥n0​

Typical usage: any compare based sorting algorithm requires Ω(nlog⁡n)\Omega(n \log{n})Ω(nlogn) compares in the worst case.

Asymptotic Tight Bounds - Big Θ\ThetaΘ

f(n)f(n)f(n) is Θ(g(n))\Theta(g(n))Θ(g(n)) if there exist constants c1>0c_1 > 0c1​>0, c2>0c_2 > 0c2​>0 and n0≥0n_0 \geq 0n0​≥0 such that:

0≤c1⋅g(n)≤f(n)≤c2⋅g(n) for all n≥n00 \leq c_1 \cdot g(n) \leq f(n) \leq c_2 \cdot g(n) \text{ for all } n\geq n_00≤c1​⋅g(n)≤f(n)≤c2​⋅g(n) for all n≥n0​

Typical usage: mergesort makes Θ(nlog⁡n)\Theta(n\log{n})Θ(nlogn) compares to sort nnn elements.

An asymptotically tight bound can also be obtained by computing a limit as nnn goes to infinity. Let f(n)f(n)f(n) and g(n)g(n)g(n), such that:

lim⁡n→∞f(n)g(n)=c\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{f(n)}{g(n)} = cn→∞lim​g(n)f(n)​=c

Therefore f(n)=Ω(g(n))f(n) = \Omega(g(n))f(n)=Ω(g(n)).

Other propositions include:

  • if lim⁡n→∞f(n)g(n)=0\lim_{n\to\infty} \frac{f(n)}{g(n)} = 0limn→∞​g(n)f(n)​=0, then f(n)∈O(g(n))f(n) \in O(g(n))f(n)∈O(g(n)) but not in Ω(g(n))\Omega(g(n))Ω(g(n))
  • if lim⁡n→∞f(n)g(n)=∞\lim_{n\to\infty} \frac{f(n)}{g(n)} = \inftylimn→∞​g(n)f(n)​=∞, then f(n)∈Ω(g(n))f(n) \in \Omega(g(n))f(n)∈Ω(g(n)) but not in O(g(n))O(g(n))O(g(n))

Properties of Asymptotic Growth Rates

  • Reflexivity: f∈O(f)f \in O(f)f∈O(f)
  • Constants: if fff is O(g1)O(g_1)O(g1​) and c>0c > 0c>0, then cf∈O(g)cf \in O(g)cf∈O(g).

  • Products: if f1f_1f1​ is O(g1)O(g_1)O(g1​) and f2f_2f2​ is O(g2)O(g_2)O(g2​) then f1f2∈O(g1g2)f_1f_2 \in O(g_1g_2)f1​f2​∈O(g1​g2​)

    • Proof:
    ∃c1>0 and n1≥0 such that 0≤f1(n)≤c1⋅g1(n)∀n≥n1∃c2>0 and n2≥0 such that 0≤f2(n)≤c2⋅g2(n)∀n≥n20≤f1(n)⋅f2(n)≤c1⋅c2⋅g1(n)⋅g2(n)∀n≥max{n1,n2}.\exists c_1 > 0 \text{ and } n_1 \geq 0 \text{ such that } 0 \leq f_1(n) \leq c_1 \cdot g_1(n) \forall n \geq n_1 \\ \exists c_2 > 0 \text{ and } n2 \geq 0 \text{ such that } 0 \leq f_2(n) \leq c_2 \cdot g_2(n) \forall n \geq n_2 \\ 0 \leq f_1(n) \cdot f_2(n) \leq c_1 \cdot c_2 \cdot g_1(n) \cdot g_2(n) \forall n \geq max\{n_1, n_2\}.∃c1​>0 and n1​≥0 such that 0≤f1​(n)≤c1​⋅g1​(n)∀n≥n1​∃c2​>0 and n2≥0 such that 0≤f2​(n)≤c2​⋅g2​(n)∀n≥n2​0≤f1​(n)⋅f2​(n)≤c1​⋅c2​⋅g1​(n)⋅g2​(n)∀n≥max{n1​,n2​}.
  • Sums: if f1f_1f1​ is O(g1)O(g_1)O(g1​) and f2f_2f2​ is O(g2)O(g_2)O(g2​), then f1+f2f_1 + f_2f1​+f2​ is O(max{g1,g2})O(max\{g_1, g_2\})O(max{g1​,g2​})
  • Transitivity: if fff is O(g)O(g)O(g) and ggg is O(h)O(h)O(h), then f∈O(h)f \in O(h)f∈O(h)

Asymptotic Bounds for Some Common Functions

Let's consider properties of the most basic and common functions: polynomials, logarithms, and exponentials.

Polynomials

Asymptotic rate of growth of polynomial functions is determined by their high order term. Therefore, let fff be a polynomial of a degree ddd in which a coefficient ada_dad​ is positive, then f=O(nd)f = O(n^d)f=O(nd).

Logarithms

Logarithms are very slowly growing functions. For every base bbb, the function log⁡bn\log_b{n}logb​n is asymptotically bounded to every function of the form nxn^xnx. For every b>1b > 1b>1 and every x>0x > 0x>0, log⁡bn=O(nx)\log_b{n} = O(n^x)logb​n=O(nx). log⁡an\log_a{n}loga​n is Θ(log⁡bn)\Theta(\log_b{n})Θ(logb​n) for every a>1a > 1a>1 and every b>1b > 1b>1.

Exponential

Exponential function grow faster than polynomials. For every r>1r > 1r>1 and every d>0d > 0d>0, we have nd=O(rn)n^d = O(r^n)nd=O(rn) and lim⁡n→∞ndrn=0\lim_{n\to\infty} \frac{n^d}{r^n} = 0limn→∞​rnnd​=0

Factorials

n! is 2Θ(nlog⁡n)n! \text{ is } 2^{\Theta(n\log{n})}n! is 2Θ(nlogn)

Big O Notation with Multiple Variables

f(m,n)f(m, n)f(m,n) is O(g(m,n))O(g(m, n))O(g(m,n)) if there exist constant c>0c > 0c>0, m0≥0m_0 \geq 0m0​≥0, and n0≥0n_0 \geq 0n0​≥0 such that:

f(m,n)≤c⋅g(m,n) for all n≥n0 and m≥m0f(m, n) \leq c \cdot g(m, n) \text{ for all } n \geq n_0 \text{ and } m \geq m_0f(m,n)≤c⋅g(m,n) for all n≥n0​ and m≥m0​

Breadth first search takes O(m+n)O(m + n)O(m+n) time to find a shortest path from sss to ttt in a digraph with nnn nodes and mmm edges.

Notation for graphs: G=(V,E)G = (V, E)G=(V,E)

  • VVV - set of nodes/vertices
  • EEE - set of edges between pairs of nodes

Graphs capture pairwise relationship between objects. Graph size parameters: n=∣V∣n = |V|n=∣V∣, m=∣E∣m = |E|m=∣E∣.

Adjacency matrix

Adjacency matrix is a n-by-n matrix with Auv=1A_{uv} = 1Auv​=1, if (u,v)(u, v)(u,v) is an edge:

  • There are two representations of each edge
  • Space proportional to n2n^2n2
  • Checking if (u,v)(u, v)(u,v) is an edge takes Θ(1)\Theta(1)Θ(1) time
  • Identifying all edges takes Θ(n2)\Theta(n^2)Θ(n2) time

Adjacency list

Adjacency lists are node-indexed arrays of lists:

  • Two representations of each edge
  • Space is Θ(m+n)\Theta(m + n)Θ(m+n)
  • Checking if (u,v)(u, v)(u,v) is an edge takes O(degree(u))O(degree(u))O(degree(u)) time, where degree is number of neighbors of uuu
  • Identifying all edges takes Θ(m+n)\Theta(m + n)Θ(m+n) time

Paths and connectivity

A path is an undirected graph GGG that contains a sequence of nodes with property that each consecutive pair vi−1,viv_{i - 1}, v_ivi−1​,vi​ joined by an edge in EEE. A path is simple if all nodes are distinct. An undirected graph is connected if for every pair of nodes uuu and vvv, there is a path between uuu and vvv.

A cycle is a path in which v1=vkv_1 = v_kv1​=vk​, k>2k > 2k>2 and the first k−1k - 1k−1 nodes are all distinct.

Trees

An undirected graph is a tree if it is connected and does not contain a cycle. Let GGG be an undirected graph on nnn nodes. Any two of the following statements imply the third:

  • GGG is connected
  • GGG does not contain a cycle
  • GGG has n−1n - 1n−1 edges

Connectivity

s−ts-ts−t connectivity problem given two nodes sss and ttt, is there a path between them?. s−ts-ts−t shortest path problem given two nodes sss and ttt, what is the length of a shortest path between sss and ttt?

Breadth-first search (BFS)

The simplest algorithm to determine s−ts-ts−t connectivity. BFS explores nodes outward from sss in all possible directions, adding nodes one layer at a time. Steps performed by BFS:

  1. L0={s}L_0 = \{s\}L0​={s}
  2. L1= all neighbors of L0L_1 = \text{ all neighbors of } L_0L1​= all neighbors of L0​
  3. L2= all nodes that do not belong to L0 or L1 and that have an edge to a node in L1L_2 = \text{ all nodes that do not belong to } L_0 \text{ or } L_1 \text{ and that have an edge to a node in } L_1L2​= all nodes that do not belong to L0​ or L1​ and that have an edge to a node in L1​
  4. Li+1= all nodes that do not belong to an earlier layer and that have an edge to a node in LiL_{i + 1} = \text{ all nodes that do not belong to an earlier layer and that have an edge to a node in } L_iLi+1​= all nodes that do not belong to an earlier layer and that have an edge to a node in Li​
BFS(s):
  discovered[s] = true
  for all nodes v:
    discovered[v] = false

  initialize L[0] = [s]
  layer counter i = 0
  BFS tree T = {}

  while L[i] is not empty:
    L[i + 1] = []

    for each node u in L[i]:
      (u, v) = edge incident to u 
      if not discovered[v]:
        discovered[v] = true
        T.push((u, v))
        L[i + 1].add(v)

    i += 1

The above implementation of the BFS algorithm runs in O(m+n)O(m + n)O(m+n) if the graph is given by the adjacency list representation.

Theorem. For each iii, LiL_iLi​ consists of all nodes at distance exactly iii from sss. There is a path from sss to ttt if and only if ttt appears in some layer.

BFS produces a tree TTT, rooted at sss on the set of nodes reachable from sss. Specifically, for each node vvv (other than sss).

Property. Let TTT be a BFS tree of G=(V,E)G = (V, E)G=(V,E) and let (x,y)(x, y)(x,y) be an edge of GGG. Then, the levels of xxx and yyy differ by at most 1.

Analysis of BFS:

Theorem. The above implementation of BFS runs in O(m+n)O(m + n)O(m+n) time if the graph is given by its adjacency representation.

Proof:

  • Easy to prove O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2) running time:

    • at most nnn lists L[i]L[i]L[i]
    • each node occurs on at most one list; for loop runs ≤n\leq n≤n times
    • when we consider node uuu there are ≤n\leq n≤n incident edges (u,v)(u, v)(u,v)
    • and we spend O(1)O(1)O(1) processing each edge

  • Actually runs in O(m+n)O(m + n)O(m+n) time:

    • when we consider node uuu, there are degree(u)degree(u)degree(u) incident edges (u,v)(u, v)(u,v)
    • total time processing edges is Σu∈Vdegree(u)=2m\Sigma_{u \in V} degree(u) = 2mΣu∈V​degree(u)=2m

Connected Component

The set of nodes discovered by the BFS algorithm is precisely those reachable from the starting node sss. Let RRR be the connected component of GGG containing sss. Once the connected component is known, we can simply check whether ttt belongs to it in order to determine s−ts-ts−t connectivity.

R will consist of nodes to which s has a path
R = {s}
while there is an edge (u, v), where u in R and v not in R:
  add v to R

Upon termination, RRR is the connected component containing sss.

Depth-first Search (DFS)

DFS algorithm explores GGG by going as deeply as possible and only retreating when necessary.

DFS(u):
  mark u as 'explored' and add u to R
  for rach edge (u, v) incident to u:
    if v is not 'explored':
      DFS(v)

To apply this to s−ts-ts−t connectivity problem, we simply declare all nodes initially to be not explored and invoke DFS(s).

DFS and BFS are similar in a way that they both build the connected component containing sss. While DFS visits the same set of nodes that BFS does, it does it in a different order.

Bipartite Graphs

An undirected graph G=(V,E)G = (V, E)G=(V,E) is bipartite if the nodes can be colored blue or white such that every edge has one white and one blue end.

Many graph problems become:

  • Easier if the underlying graph is bipartite (matching)
  • Tractable if the underlying graph is bipartite (independent set)

Lemma. If a graph GGG is bipartite, it cannot contain odd-length cycle.

Lemma. Let GGG be a connected graph and let L0,...,LkL_0, ..., L_kL0​,...,Lk​ be the layers produced by BFS starting node sss. Exactly one of the following holds:

  • No edge in GGG joins two nodes of the same layer, and GGG is bipartite

    • Proof. Suppose no edge joins two nodes in same layer. By BFS property, each edge joins two nodes in adjacent levels. Bipartition: white = nodes on odd levels, blue = nodes on even levels.

  • An edge of GGG joins two nodes of the same layer, and GGG contains an odd-length cycle and hence not bipartite

    • Proof. Suppose (x,y)(x, y)(x,y) is an edge with x,yx, yx,y in the same level LjL_jLj​. Let z=lca(x,y)z = lca(x, y)z=lca(x,y) = lowest common ancestor. Let LiL_iLi​ be a level containing zzz. Consider cycle that takes edge from xxx to yyy, then path from yyy to zzz, then path from zzz to xxx. Its length is 1+(j−i)+(j−i)1 + (j - i) + (j - i)1+(j−i)+(j−i) which is odd.

Corollary. A graph is bipartite if and only if it contains no odd-length cycle.

Connectivity in Directed Graphs

Direct reachability: Given a node sss find all nodes reachable from sss. Directed s−ts-ts−t shortest path problem: given two nodes sss and ttt what is the length of a shortest path between them.

BFS extends naturally to directed graphs.

Strong Connectivity

Nodes uuu and vvv are mutually reachable if there is both a path from uuu to vvv and also a path from vvv to uuu. A graph is strongly connected if a pair of nodes is mutually reachable.

Lemma. Let sss be any node. GGG is strongly connected if and only if every node is reachable from sss and sss is reachable from every node.

Algorithm:

Theorem: Can determine if GGG is strongly connected in O(m+n)O(m + n)O(m+n) time.

Proof:

  • Pick any node sss
  • Run BFS from sss in GGG
  • Run BFS from sss in GreverseG^{reverse}Greverse (reverse orientation of every edge in GGG)
  • Return true iff all nodes reached in both BFS executions
  • Correctness follows immediately from previous lemma.

Strong Components

A strong component is a maximal subset of mutually reachable nodes.

Theorem: can find all strong components in O(m+n)O(m + n)O(m+n) time.

Theorem. Can find all strong components in O(m+n)O(m + n)O(m+n) time.

Directed Acyclic Graphs and Topological Ordering

A DAG is a directed graph that contains no directed cycles. A topological order of a directed graph G=(V,E)G = (V, E)G=(V,E) is an ordering of its nodes as v1,v2,…,vnv_1, v_2, \ldots, v_nv1​,v2​,…,vn​ so that every edge (vi,vj)(v_i, v_j)(vi​,vj​) we have i<ji < ji<j.

Precedence constraints: edge (vi,vj)(v_i, v_j)(vi​,vj​) means task viv_ivi​ must occur before vjv_jvj​.

Lemma. If GGG has a topological order, then GGG is a DAG. Proof (by contradiction):

  • Suppose that GGG has a topological order v1,v2,...,vnv_1, v_2, ..., v_nv1​,v2​,...,vn​ and that GGG also has a directed cycle CCC.
  • Let viv_ivi​ be the lowest indexed node in CCC and let vjv_jvj​ be the node just before viv_ivi​, therefore (vj,vi)(v_j, v_i)(vj​,vi​) is an edge
  • we have i<ji < ji<j
  • Since (vj,vi)(v_j, v_i)(vj​,vi​) is an edge and v1,v2,...,vnv_1, v_2, ..., v_nv1​,v2​,...,vn​ is a topological order, we must have j<ij < ij<i, a contradiction

Lemma. If GGG has a topological order, then GGG is a DAG.

Lemma. If GGG is a DAG, then GGG has a node with no entering edges. Proof (by contradiction):

  • Suppose that GGG is a DAG and every node has at least one entering edge
  • Pick a node vvv and begin following edges backwards from vvv. Since vvv has at least one entering edge (u,v)(u, v)(u,v) we can walk backward to uuu
  • Then since uuu has at least one entering edge (x,u)(x, u)(x,u) we can walk backward to xxx
  • Repeat until we visit www twice
  • Let CCC denote the sequence of nodes encountered between successive visits to www. CCC is a cycle.

Lemma. If GGG is a DAG, then GGG has a topological ordering. Proof (by induction on n):

  • Base case: true if n = 1
  • Given DAG on n>1n > 1n>1 find a node vvv with no entering edges
  • G−{v}G - \{v\}G−{v} is a DAG since deleting vvv cannot create cycles
  • By inductive hypothesis, G−{v}G - \{v\}G−{v} has a topological ordering
  • Place vvv first in topological ordering, then append nodes of G−{v}G - \{v\}G−{v}
  • In topological order. This is valid since vvv has no entering edges

Theorem. Algorithm finds a topological order in O(m+n)O(m + n)O(m+n) time. Proof:

  • Maintain the following information;

    • count(w) = remaining number of incoming edges
    • S = set of remaining nodes with no incoming edges
  • Initialization: O(m+n)O(m + n)O(m+n) via a single scan through graph

  • Update: to delete vvv:

    • remove vvv from SSS
    • decrement count(w) for all edges from vvv to www and add www to SSS if count(w) == 0
    • O(1)O(1)O(1) per edge

Theory is when one understands everything but nothing works. Practice is when everything works but nobody understands why.

Stable Matching Problem

The Stable Matching Problem originated when David Gale and Lloyd Shapley, two mathematical economists decided to design a college admissions process, or a job recruiting process that was self-enforcing.

Given a set of preferences among employers and applicants, can we assign applicants to employers so that for every employer EEE, and every applicant AAA, who is not scheduled to work for EEE, at least one of the following two things is the case?

  1. EEE prefers every one of its accepted applicants to AAA; or
  2. AAA prefers her current situation over working for employer EEE.

If this holds, the outcome is stable: individual self-interest will prevent any applicant/employer deal from being made behind the scenes.

Goal. Given a set of preferences among hospitals and med-school students, design a self-reinforcing admissions process.

Unstable pair. Hospital hhh and student sss form an unstable pair if both:

  1. hhh prefers sss to one of its admitted students.
  2. sss prefers hhh to assigned hospital.

Stable assignment. Assignment with no unstable pairs.

  • Natural and desirable condition.
  • Individual self-interest prevents any side deals.

Consider a set H={h1,…,hn}H = \{h_1, \ldots, h_n\}H={h1​,…,hn​} of nnn hospitals, and a set S={s1,…,sn}S = \{s_1, \ldots,s_n\}S={s1​,…,sn​} of nnn students. Let H×SH \times SH×S denote the set of all possible ordered pairs of the form (h,s)(h, s)(h,s), where h∈Hh \in Hh∈H and s∈Ss \in Ss∈S.

Matching & Perfect Matching

  • A matching set MMM is a set of ordered pairs, each from H×SH \times SH×S, with the property that each member of HHH and each members of SSS appears in at most one pair in MMM.
  • A perfect matching M′M'M′ is a matching with the property that each member of HHH and each member of SSS appears in exactly one pair in M′M'M′. A matching MMM is perfect if:
∣M∣=∣H∣=∣S∣=n|M| = |H| = |S| = n∣M∣=∣H∣=∣S∣=n

Unstable Pair

Given a perfect matching MMM, hospital hhh and student sss form an unstable pair if both:

  1. hhh prefers sss to matched student
  2. sss prefers hhh to matched student

Given all that information, we can describe stable matching:

A stable matching is a perfect matching with no unstable pairs. Stable matching problem can be described as:

Given the preference list of nnn hospitals and nnn students, find a stable matching (if one exists).

It is not obvious a priori if stable matchings always exist.

Gale-Shapley Algorithm

function stableMatching {
  // Initialize all m ∈ M and w ∈ W to free
  while ∃ hospital h is unmatched and still has a student s to propose to {
     s = first student on h’s list to whom h has not yet proposed
     if s is unmatched
       (h, s) added to M
     else some pair (h', s) already exists
       if s prefers h to h'
          s rejects h'
         (h, s) is added to M
       else
         (h', s) remain in M
  }
}

Proof of correctness: Termination

  • Hospitals propose to students in decreasing order of preference
  • Once a student is matched, the student never becomes unmatched, only 'trades up'

Claim: Algorithm terminates after at most n2n^2n2 iterations of while loop. Proof: Each time through the while loop, a hospital proposes to a new student. Thus, there are at most n2n^2n2 possible proposals.

Proof of correctness: Perfect matching

  1. Claim: Gale-Shapley outputs a matching. Proof:

    • Hospitals proposes only if unmatched →\to→ matched to ≤\leq≤ 1 student
    • Student keeps only best hospital →\to→ matched to ≤\leq≤ 1 hospital

  2. Claim: In Gale-Shapley matching, all hospitals get matched. Proof (by contradiction):

    • Suppose that some hospital h∈Hh \in Hh∈H is unmatched upon termination of G-S algorithm
    • Then, some student s∈Ss \in Ss∈S is unmatched upon termination
    • Therefore, sss was never proposed to
    • However, hhh proposes to every student, since hhh ends up unmatched.

  3. Claim: In Gale-Shapley matching, all students get matched. Proof (by counting):

    • By previous claim, all nnn hospitals het matched
    • Thus, all nnn students get matched.

Proof of correctness: Stability

Claim: In G-S matching M∗M^{*}M∗, there are no unstable pairs. Proof: Consider any pair (h,s)(h, s)(h,s) that is not in M∗M^{*}M∗:

  1. Case 1: hhh never proposed to sss:

    • hhh prefers its G-S partner to s′s's′ (hospitals propose in decreasing order of preference)
    • (h,s)(h, s)(h,s) is not unstable

  2. Case 2: hhh proposed to sss

    • sss rejected hhh (either right away or later)
    • sss prefers G-S partner h′h'h′ to hhh (students only trade up)
    • (h,s)(h, s)(h,s) is not unstable

In either case, the pair (h,s)(h, s)(h,s) is not unstable.

The Gale-Shapley algorithm guarantees to find a stable matching for any problem instance.

Hospital optimality

Student sss is a valid partner for hospital hhh if there exists any stable matching in which hhh and sss are matched. Hospital optimal assignment is when each hospital receives best valid partner. All executions of G-S yield hospital-optimal assignment. Hospital-optimal assignemtn is a stable matching.

Claim: G-S matching M∗M^{*}M∗ is hospital-optimal. Proof (by contradiction):

  • Suppose a hospital is matchied with student other than best valid partner
  • Hospitals propose in decreasing order of preference (some hospital is rejected by a valid partner during G-S)
  • Let hhh be first such hospital, and let sss be the first valid partner that rejects hhh
  • Let MMM be a stable matching where hhh and sss are matched
  • When sss rejects hhh in Gale-Shapley, sss forms (of re-affirms) commintment to a h′h'h′ => sss prefers h′h'h′ to hhh
  • Let s′s's′ be partner of h′h'h′ in MMM
  • h′h'h′ had not been rejected by any valid partner (including s′s's′) at the point when hhh is rejected by sss.
  • Thus, h′h'h′ had not yet proposed to s′s's′ when h′h'h′ proposed to sss => hhh prefers sss to s′s's′
  • Thus, (h′,s)(h', s)(h′,s) is unstable in MMM, a contradiction.

Student-pessimal assignment: each student receives worst valid partner.

Claim: G-S finds student-pessimal stable matching M∗M^{*}M∗. Proof (by contradiction):

  • Suppose (h,s)(h, s)(h,s) matched in M∗M^{*}M∗ but hhh is not the worst valid partner for sss
  • There exists stable matching MMM in which sss is paired with a hospital h′h'h′ whom sss prefers less than hhh => sss prefers hhh to h′h'h′
  • Let s′s's′ be the partner of hhh in MMM
  • By hospital-optimality, sss is the best valid partner for hhh => hhh prefers sss to s′s's′
  • Thus (h,s)(h, s)(h,s) is an unstable pair in MMM, a contradiction.
